title: Is there a startup movement in the Dominican Republic? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are several organizations promoting an entrepreneurial spirit in the country, like Startup Weekend Santo Domingo and Santiago, Chispa Emprendedora, etc. We have local talent from institutions like INTEC (Santo Domingo Institute of Technology), ITLA (Las Americas Institute of Technology), etc. The Dominican Republic has a vibrant and growing economy. With an excellent telecommunication infrastructure, a highly developed industrial free trade zone network, a stable economy and a tradition of democratic governments for over the last 3 decades, the Dominican Republic offers the best location for investments in various sectors such as electronic commerce, high-tech manufacturing, telecommunications, energy, and tourism. The country is geographically gifted. It's convenience to all markets is desirably located in the center of the Caribbean Sea, it is close to the United States and serves as a strategic connection between Central, South and North America, and Europe. The country's advantages are great and many: Political and macroeconomic stabilityTrained labor poolLow operating costsSuperb telecommunications infrastructureDeveloped banking and insurance systemRisk free commercial zones operating environmentAttractive fiscal and financial incentivesExcellent training programs to enhance labor skills and increase productivityStrategic geographic location; easy accessibilityIs true Santo Domingo has a long way to really become a Startup-friendly city, but we're starting and our young population is making it happen.

It is true that there are a lot of programs available. However, even if you get the aid you need consider that a) people dont like to pay you so they will either wait several months with an excuse so you give in and accept less money (even the big companies do this) and b) everything is socially based meaning that if someone doesnt like you because you wouldnt say hi then they make it their mission to create obstacles. It is extremely difficult to do business unless you are a multinational and/or have a lot of cash and are willing to put yourself in debt in order to maintain your business. That said any and all foreign “startup movement” that may be available (not that i am aware of) is more likely to actually provide the proper assistance and support to startups. There is no reliable way at the moment other than keeping in mind that you may have to struggle and deal with a lot of things for 5–10 years. After that it may be a profitable endeavor. It is not impossible but you should know the reality of it and create your own opportunities. This culture does not follow the entrepreneur spirit of a lot of countries, it is a different culture and should be approached accordingly. You could also approach companies that might be interested in investing in your ideas or project but keep in mind they might use it without your permission (it happens a lot). Best of luck
